subjects.name: JavaScript Programming
subjects.description: Master JavaScript from basics to advanced concepts

topics.title: Introduction to JavaScript
topics.description: Learn what JavaScript is and why it's important

contents.title: What is JavaScript?
contents.content:
JavaScript is a versatile programming language that powers the interactive elements of websites. It runs in web browsers and enables dynamic content, user interactions, and modern web applications.

Key features of JavaScript:
‚Ä¢ Runs in the browser (client-side)
‚Ä¢ Easy to learn for beginners
‚Ä¢ Powers modern web frameworks like React, Vue, and Angular
‚Ä¢ Can also run on servers using Node.js

contents.title: Your First JavaScript Code

examples.title: Printing Messages
examples.code:
console.log('Welcome to JavaScript!');
console.log('Learning is fun!');
examples.explanation: The console.log() function prints messages to the browser's console. You can use it to display text, numbers, or any data.

examples.title: Using Variables
examples.explanation: Variables store data that you can use later. The 'let' keyword creates a variable that can be changed.

topics.title: Variables and Data Types
topics.description: Understanding how to store and work with different types of data

contents.title: Declaring Variables
contents.content:
In JavaScript, you can declare variables using three keywords:

‚Ä¢ let - for variables that can change
‚Ä¢ const - for variables that stay constant
‚Ä¢ var - old way (avoid using this)

Best practice: Use 'const' by default, and 'let' only when you need to change the value.

contents.title: Variable Examples
Data Types in JavaScript
contents.content:
JavaScript has several data types:

1. String - Text data ('hello', "world")
2. Number - Numeric data (42, 3.14)
3. Boolean - True or false values
4. Array - List of values [1, 2, 3]
5. Object - Collection of key-value pairs
6. Undefined - Variable declared but not assigned
7. Null - Intentionally empty value

contents.title: Data Type Examples

examples.title: Working with Strings
examples.explanation: You can combine strings using the + operator. This is called string concatenation.

examples.title: Working with Numbers
examples.explanation: JavaScript can perform mathematical operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

topics.title: Functions in JavaScript
topics.description: Learn how to create reusable blocks of code

contents.title: What are Functions?
contents.content:
Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. They help you:

‚Ä¢ Organize your code
‚Ä¢ Avoid repetition
‚Ä¢ Make code easier to maintain
‚Ä¢ Break complex problems into smaller parts

Think of functions like recipes - you write them once and use them many times!

contents.title: Creating Functions

examples.title: Function with Multiple Parameters
examples.explanation: This function takes two parameters (length and width) and returns their product. You can use the returned value in your code.

examples.title: Arrow Functions (Modern Syntax)
examples.explanation: Arrow functions are a shorter way to write functions. They're commonly used in modern JavaScript.

contents.title: What is Python?
contents.content:
Python is a popular, easy-to-learn programming language used for:

‚Ä¢ Web development (Django, Flask)
‚Ä¢ Data science and machine learning
‚Ä¢ Automation and scripting
‚Ä¢ Game development
‚Ä¢ Desktop applications

Python is known for its simple, readable syntax that looks almost like English!

contents.title: Your First Python Program
contents.content:
# This is a comment
print('Hello, World!')

# Variables in Python
name = 'Student'
age = 20

print('My name is', name)
print('I am', age, 'years old')

examples.title: Print Function
examples.code:
print('Welcome to Python!')
print('Python is awesome!')
print(2 + 2)  # Output: 4
examples.explanation: The print() function displays output to the screen. You can print text, numbers, or results of calculations.

examples.title: Variables in Python
examples.code:
# No need for let or const in Python!
name = 'Raj'
city = 'Bangalore'
age = 25

print(f'My name is {name}')
print(f'I live in {city}')
print(f'I am {age} years old')
examples.explanation: Python uses f-strings for easy string formatting. Just put 'f' before the string and use {variable} to insert values.

contents.title: Basic Data Types
contents.content:
Python has several built-in data types:

‚Ä¢ int - Whole numbers (1, 42, -10)
‚Ä¢ float - Decimal numbers (3.14, -0.5)
‚Ä¢ str - Text strings ('hello', "world")
‚Ä¢ bool - True or False
‚Ä¢ list - Ordered collection [1, 2, 3]
‚Ä¢ dict - Key-value pairs {'name': 'Raj'}
‚Ä¢ tuple - Immutable list (1, 2, 3)
‚Ä¢ set - Unique values {1, 2, 3}

contents.title: Working with Data Types
contents.content:
# Numbers
age = 25              # int
price = 99.99         # float

# Strings
name = 'Priya'
city = "Mumbai"

# Boolean
is_student = True
has_passed = False

# List (can be modified)
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']
fruits.append('mango')

# Dictionary
person = {
    'name': 'Amit',
    'age': 30,
    'city': 'Delhi'
}

print(person['name'])  # Output: Amit

examples.title: List Operations
examples.code:
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# Add item
numbers.append(6)

# Remove item
numbers.remove(3)

# Get length
print(len(numbers))

# Access by index
print(numbers[0])  # First item
examples.explanation: Lists are versatile and can store multiple items. You can add, remove, and access items easily.
